questions.q: What is the purpose of system calls?
questions.explanation: System calls provide an interface between user-level processes and the operating system kernel, allowing processes to request OS services.
questions.answer: System calls allow user-level processes to request services of the operating system

questions.q: What are the five major activities of an operating system with regard to process management?
questions.explanation: These five activities cover the complete lifecycle and interaction management of processes in an operating system.
questions.answer: Creation and deletion of processes, suspension and resumption of processes, provision of mechanisms for process synchronization, provision of mechanisms for process communication, and provision of mechanisms for deadlock handling

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT one of the three major activities of an operating system with regard to memory management?
questions.explanation: The three major memory management activities are: tracking memory usage, deciding which processes to load, and allocating/deallocating memory. Encryption is not a core memory management activity.
options: Keeping track of which parts of memory are being used
Deciding which processes to load into memory

questions.q: What are the three major activities of an operating system with regard to secondary-storage management?
questions.explanation: Secondary-storage management focuses on managing free space, allocating storage efficiently, and scheduling disk operations.
options: Free-space management, storage allocation, and disk scheduling

questions.q: Why is the command interpreter usually separate from the kernel?
questions.explanation: The command interpreter reads and executes commands, converting them into system calls. It's kept separate from the kernel because it frequently needs to be modified or updated.
options: Because the command interpreter is subject to changes
Because it runs faster when separate
Because it needs to be written in a different programming language

questions.q: In Unix systems, what two system calls need to be executed to start a new process?
questions.explanation: The fork() call clones the currently executing process, while exec() overlays a new process based on a different executable over the calling process.

questions.q: System programs can be thought of as bundles of useful system calls that provide basic functionality to users.
questions.explanation: System programs provide common functionality so users don't need to write their own programs to solve common problems using system calls directly.

questions.q: What is the main advantage of the layered approach to system design?
questions.explanation: Modular design means bugs are limited to specific modules/layers, information is kept where needed, and changes don't affect the entire system.
options: The system is easier to debug and modify because changes affect only limited sections
It makes the system run faster
It allows multiple operating systems to run simultaneously

questions.q: Which of the following OS services could NOT be safely provided by user-level programs?
questions.explanation: User-level programs cannot be trusted to properly allocate CPU time, access devices appropriately, enforce file protections, coordinate network access, or handle system-wide errors. These all require OS-level control.
options: All of the listed services require OS-level control
Program execution and CPU time allocation

questions.q: Why do some systems store the operating system in firmware rather than on disk?
questions.explanation: Devices without traditional disk storage, such as handheld PDAs and cellular telephones, must store their operating system in firmware.
options: For devices like PDAs and cellular phones that may not have a disk with a file system available
Because firmware is faster than disk storage

questions.q: How does a boot manager allow a choice of operating systems from which to boot?
questions.explanation: Rather than booting directly to an OS, the boot manager runs first during startup, presents a menu of available operating systems, and boots into a default OS if no selection is made.
questions.answer: The boot manager runs during system startup and determines which OS to boot into, typically stored at specific hard disk locations and providing a selection menu
